DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Attack Army Patrol, Kill 10 Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas from the nation's largest insurgent group ambushed an army patrol in southern Colombia on Saturday, killing 10 soldiers, an army communique said. The attack came just hours after another leftist guerrilla group, the April 19 Movement, announced it had suspended a tentative peace pact after Congress failed to approved key parts of the accord. Guerrillas belonging to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia blew up part of the road south of the town of San Martin as an army patrol traveling in three vehicles passed over it, the communique said. The insurgents then opened fire on the patrol with automatic weapons and rockets, killing 10 soldiers and injuring an undetermined number, said the communique, read in a radio broadcast by the Caracol network. The communique added that forces from the army's 7th Brigade were still fighting the guerrillas who perpetrated the attack. San Martin is 65 miles south of Bogota in Meta state. Founded about 30 years ago, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, with its estimated 5,000 armed rebels, is the oldest and largest of Colombia's six main guerrilla groups. Another group, the April 19 Movment, said Saturday that it would not lay down its weapons and accept a government amnesty this month as originally planned. The movement cited as the reason for its decision Congress's failure to approve key points of an official peace plan, which were included in legislation to reform the country's constitution. The Senate shelved the legislation Dec. 14, after the House attached a bill allowing a national vote on Colombia's extradition of drug traffickers. The Senate apparently accepted President Virgilio Barco's argument that the extradition referendum would lead to increased terrorist violence by traffickers trying to pressure the public into rejecting extradition. The shelving of the reform legislation was viewed as a victory for the Barco administration's struggle against traffickers but a blow to its efforts to make peace with the April 19 Movement and other leftist groups. The legislation would have created a special electoral system allowing the movement to elect members to Congress with fewer votes than normally required. The group had demanded the concession in return for its agreement to lay down its arms. A joint communique issued Saturday by the April 19 Movement's leaders and government negotiators said the agreement has been suspended but not discarded. ``Its contents are still valid, and its negotiators have the responsibility to make it a reality,'' the communique said. Both sides expressed ``the will to continue seeking dialogue and negotiation.'' A new round of talks to save the pact is to begin in January.
